Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Language plasticity - Genes, Brain, Cognition and Computation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award establishes a unique interdisciplinary training program that prepares Ph.D. scientists from cognitive (linguistics, psychology, communication disorders) and biological fields (molecular genetics, behavior genetics, neuroscience) to achieve a unified cognitive-biological understanding of human language development. Innovations from this approach will address societal challenges in education, technology, and health.

Intellectual Merit: A full understanding of human language ? including genetic, neural, cognitive and environmental influences that shape language development and recovery from brain injury ? requires linking a vast array of biological and cognitive sciences. Conventional approaches to graduate training produce cognitive and biological language scientists with little technical overlap ? a barrier to communication. Trainees will develop expertise in their home domains and rigorous interdisciplinary training, providing broad and deep knowledge of theories and methods of other domains to communicate, collaborate and innovate in multidisciplinary teams. The training program uses a team-based model, in an environment designed to foster creativity and innovation ? along with integrated coursework and training in how to translate that research to educational, technological, and health applications.

Broader Impacts: This IGERT award will prepare a new generation of leaders to conduct (and train others to conduct) the team-based basic and applied research needed to achieve a unified biological-cognitive science of language. Key components include: training to communicate with educators, policy makers and the public in innovative ways that address societal challenges in technology and education; comprehensive efforts to increase participation among historically underrepresented groups in science; and preparing trainees for the increasingly international scientific community through on-site and internet-based opportunities to connect with leading cognitive and biological centers of language research around the world.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IGERT project on "Language Plasticity" led to the founding of a new, interdisciplinary training program for Ph.D. students in "Neurobiology of Language" at the University of Connecticut. Our motivation was the observation that scientists in many cognitive and biological fields work on language, but have litttle contact with each other.

  • Linguists create formal theories of language structure
  • Psychologists use experiments to test theories of how language develops and is processed in connection with other cognitive abilities
  • Neuroscientists chart the neurobiological basis of language and related abilities
  • Clinical scientists study atypical language in developmental conditions like dyslexia or autism or acquired disorders due to stroke or traumatic brain injury
  • Geneticists examine genetic bases for typical and atypical language development

Our vision was to accelerate scientific progress by bringing Ph.D. students from all these fields together in a program designed to provide them with "just enough" knowledge of each field to promote interdisciplinary communication and collaboration.

We funded 27 IGERT fellows for two years each. An additional 27 students participated fully in the program as unfunded associate trainees (with funding from their home Ph.D. programs). Over the course of the project, our trainees produced more than 100 peer-reviewed articles and chapters, and made more than 350 conference presentations. These publications and presentations shared with our scientific colleagues and the public substantial progress in understanding language plasticity throughout the lifespan.

These reports included several scientific accomplishments: (a) advances in understanding of the genetic and neurobiological bases of language acquisition thanks to collaborations involving linguists, geneticists, neuroscientists, and developmental, cognitive, and clinical psychologist; (b) deeper understanding of reading acquisition and dyslexia thanks to collaborations involving neuroscientists, speech-language-hearing scientists, and cognitive, developmental, and clinical psychologists; (c) better understanding of the computational challenges of spoken language comprehension thanks to collaborations involving cognitive neuroscientists, neurophysiologists, physicists, and speech-language-hearing scientists; and (d) new insights into the role of language in supporting number and social cognition thanks to collaborations between developmental psychologists, linguists, and computer scientists.

IGERT funding led to several educational achievements as well. These include: (a) a transformed training environment, with integrated reserach-based and course-based training where interdisciplinary collaboration is not exceptional but instead is the norm; (b) a culture of learning and sharing, where faculty and students actively participate in training members of our community (for example, students organize our annual "January-Term Primers" during our winter sermester break, where students and faculty attend tutorials and workshops led mostly by students); (c) a training program that will be sustained beyond NSF funding thanks to faculty commitment and student interest; (d) institutional changes, such as greater acceptance of the value of team-teaching for interdisciplinary courses; (e) improved communication skills for both students and facullty thanks to an emphasis on outreach and formal and informal instruction in science communication; and (f) a strong impact on the diversity of our graduate programs (prior to IGERT funding, 11% of trainees in our programs were from underrepresented groups; 28% of IGERT trainees were from underrepresented groups, which led to 16% overall in our participating Ph.D. programs; the recruiting mechanisms we developed under IGERT funding will continue to promote diversity in our programs). 

These research and educational achievements promoted trainee success. The major accomplishments of our trainees included: (a) excellent placement in academic careers (tenure track professors and postdocs) non-academic careers (e.g., one is a scientific liason bridging R&D and sales for a major pharmaceutical company, one is a scientist at a company making apps to promote reading development, and several about to graduate are interviewing with technology and data science companies); (b) deep and broad disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge and skill (each has Ph.D.-level expertise in their primary domain, and sufficient familiarity with multiple other disciplines to engage in interdisciplinary collaboration); (c) expertise in project management thanks to their experiences in team-based science; (d) strong communication skills thanks to our emphasis on outreach and science communication; and (e) strong problem-solving and data analytic skills fundamental to success in a broad range of careers).

In summary, IGERT funding allowed us to implement our vision of a fundamentally different approach to graduate training; one where interdisciplinary interaction and collaboration is the norm, and is part of daily work life for nearly all of our faculty and trainees. Locally and in the near-term, we have accelerated discovery in the neurobiology of language by breaking down boundaries between disciplines and getting scientists in different domains communicating and collaborating. In the long-term, our trainees are poised to put this interdisciplinary training to use in ways that will promote discovery and innovation. Their preparation will allow them to extend our approach as they move into academic and non-academic carees in ways that are easy to anticipate (doing more of the same), but we expect that they will transcend our vision in ways we cannot anticipate as well.
